title.narrative: CCR, Centre for Conflict Resolution Core support 2012-2017
CCR, Centre for Conflict Resolution Kärnstöd 2012-2017

description.narrative: The Centre for Conflict Resolution (CCR), based in South Africa, contributes to a just and sustainable peace in Africa by strengthening the capacity of African institutions and actors to manage conflicts in their own region and by influencing policy and academic debates. CCR receives programme support from Sida for 2012-2016.

The Centre for Conflict Resolution (CCR), med bas i Sydafrika, bidrar till en rättvis och hållbar fred i Afrika genom att stärka kapaciteten hos Afrikanska institutioner och aktörer att hantera konflikter i deras respektive regioner och genom att påverka policy och akademiska debatter. CCR får programstöd från Sida för 2012-2015.

The overall goal of CCR's Africa Programme is to continue to contribute towards a just and sustainable peace in Africa. The immediate objective is to strengthen the capacity of African institutions and actors to manage conflicts in their own region.

participating-org.narrative: CCR/The Centre for Conflict Resolution NPC

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Sida has provided funding of SEK 27,750,000 to the Centre for Conflict Resolution (CCR) for its Africa Programme between 1 April 2012 and 31 March 2018. During this time, CCR has worked to consolidate its pan-African vision under the theme Peacebuilding and Region-Building in Africa in its continuing efforts to contribute towards more effective conflict resolution and increased human security on the continent. The Africa Programme comprises two synergistic pillars: the Policy Development and Research (PDR) project, and the Capacity-Building and Training (CBT) project, led by CCR’s Communications and Outreach cluster. CCR has sought to respond to security and governance challenges on the continent by providing peacebuilding interventions in the form of capacity-building training in human rights, governance, and conflict management in Burundi, the DRC, Lesotho, Kenya, Rwanda, South Sudan, and Uganda. These interventions have enhanced the capacity of local peacebuilding actors and strengthened local peacebuilding mechanisms and processes to manage conflicts in the respective countries. Moreover, CCR held several policy seminars during 2014 to 2017 focusing on relationship between the AU and the RECs; these seminars form part of the ongoing debate on improving the implementation of regional integration schemes, strengthening key institutional capacities, and increasing cohesion in Africa’s region-building efforts. During the period, the Centre’s policy development and research activities have sought to contribute to conflict resolution, state-building, and post-conflict reconstruction efforts in South Sudan and the wider Great Lakes region by promoting a culture of peace through fostering dialogue between policymakers, academics, government officials, and civil society organisations. CCR’s capacity-building and training workshops have created platforms for national human rights institutions and civil society organisations to reflect on their roles in relation to conflict management and mediation, share experiences across countries, and strengthen the role of NHRIs in mainstreaming gender and promoting human rights, conflict management, mediation, and peacebuilding in collaboration with other stakeholders. Partners of CCR have noted the added value of CCR's convening function and platforms for public dialogue which have been well anchored in research, well attended and highly rated (from 2015 Sida commissioned evaluation of 5 SA think tanks).
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
